questions.text: A 60-year-old person presented with an ulcer on the medial canthus. The ulcer has rolled-out, beaded margins. Histopathology shows nesting cells with peripheral palisading patterns. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC) is the most common skin cancer and typically occurs in sun-exposed areas such as the face, particularly around the medial canthus of the eye.

The classic clinical description includes:

  • Ulceration with rolled-out, beaded margins.
  • A pearly or translucent appearance with visible telangiectasia.

Histopathology findings include:

  • Nesting of basaloid cells.
  • Peripheral palisading of nuclei.
  • Clefting artifact between tumor cells and surrounding stroma.

Other Options:

 

Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC) (Option A): Typically presents with a scaly, keratinized lesion that may ulcerate but lacks the rolled, pearly margins and palisading pattern seen in BCC.

 

Nevus (Option B): A benign lesion that does not typically ulcerate or have invasive histological features.


Melanoma (Option D): Usually presents with irregular pigmentation, asymmetry, and rapid growth, rather than a rolled-margin ulcer.

questions.text: Which carcinoma is the possible diagnosis in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct option C - Malignant melanoma

  • It presents as an irregularly shaped, dark-colored lesion with uneven borders.
  • Malignant melanoma has a higher potential to metastasize if not detected and treated early.
  • It is crucial to catch it at an early stage for a better prognosis.

Incorrect options:

Option A - Basal cell carcinoma:

  • It appears as a flesh-colored or pinkish bump with a central depression and raised edges.
  • It is slow-growing and rarely metastasizes.
  • It is common in areas exposed to the sun.

Option B - Squamous cell carcinoma:

  • It is also linked to sun exposure.
  • It presents as a firm, red nodule or a scaly, crusted lesion.
  • It has a higher potential to metastasize if left untreated.

Option D - Hepatocellular carcinoma: Hepatocellular carcinoma is a type of liver cancer that originates from hepatocytes.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic patient presents with a lesion on the nose as shown in the image below. The lesion bleeds on the touch. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Basal cell carcinoma

Explanation:

Basal cell carcinoma

  • Aka rodent ulcer
  • BCC is a slow-growing, locally invasive tumor and it rarely metastasizes.
  • It arises from pluripotent cells within the basal layer of the epidermis or follicular structures.

Clinical Features

  • It presents initially small, scaly plaque
  • Slow progressive course of peripheral extension
  • Develops into nodular-ulcerative lesions, it has a thread-like margin, telangiectasia and it bleeds on touch.

Site: Face, Around eyes, Nose

Histopathology: peripheral palisading of tumour cells (shown in the image), the cells resemble cells of stratum basale that have grown into the dermis. This cluster of cells is surrounded at the periphery by perpendicularly arranged cells. It also has a well-organized stroma surrounding it.

Treatment

  • Medical: Imiquimod, 5-FU,Intralesional interferon α-2b
  • Hedgehog pathway inhibitors:(Vismodegib)
  • Surgical:
    • Mohs micrographic surgery, Done in recurrent BCCs.

Squamous cell carcinoma (Option A):

  • Clinical Features: There is a presence of a papule, nodule, or plaque with induration, accompanied by signs of photodamage such as crusting and scaling.
  • Histopathology: Keratin pearls.

Melanoma (Option C): The image presented above doesn’t meet the diagnostic criteria of malignant melanoma (ABCDE)

  • Asymmetry: Irregular shapes.
  • Border: Irregular.
  • Colour: Various colours present or uneven distribution.
  • Diameter: > 6 mm.
  • Evolution: Changes in lesion over time (size, shape, itching, or bleeding).

Discoid lupus erythematosus (Option D): This is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by red, scaly, and atrophic lesions, typically without a tendency to bleed. Discoid lupus has distinct features like a well-demarcated, scaly plaque, and it usually lacks the ulcerative appearance seen in this case.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with the clinical condition shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Malignant melanoma

Explanation:

  • The image showing a lesion with irregular borders, asymmetry, and uneven distribution of colors, strongly suggests malignant melanoma. This is a malignant tumor arising from melanocytes located at the epidermal-dermal junction. Though rare, melanoma is highly aggressive with a significant risk of metastasis if not diagnosed early.

Key Diagnostic Features of Malignant Melanoma

  • ABCDE criteria:
    • Asymmetry.
    • Border irregularity.
    • Color variation (brown, black, red, white, or blue).
    • Diameter >6 mm.
    • Evolving lesion (changes in size, shape, or symptoms like bleeding or itching).

Biopsy Findings:

  • Large melanoma cells with enlarged nuclei, irregular contours, and clumped chromatin.
  • Prominent eosinophilic nucleoli.
  • Similar cellular appearance in both radial and vertical growth phases:
    • Radial phase: Horizontal spread of melanoma within the epidermis and superficial dermis.
    • Vertical phase: Deep invasion into dermal layers, forming an expansile mass.

Risk Factors:

  • Fair skin and history of sunburns.
  • Family history or genetic mutations (e.g., CDKN2A mutation on chromosome 9p21).
  • UV exposure and pre-existing nevi (e.g., dysplastic or congenital nevi).

Types of Melanoma:

Description

Superficial spreading (M/C type)

Any (more common on the upper back and, in women, lower legs)

Brown mixed with bluish-red, bluish-black, reddish brown, and often whitish pink. The lesion border is often visibly and/or palpably raised

Lentigo maligna

Sun-exposed surfaces, particularly malar region and temple

In flat portions, brown and tan predominate, but whitish grey sometimes present; in nodules, reddish brown, bluish grey, bluish-black.

Staging and Classification:

  • Breslow thickness: Measures depth of tumor invasion.
  • Clark level: Describes the anatomical level of invasion.

Management:

  1. Early detection and histopathological confirmation via biopsy are critical for improving outcomes.
  2. Wide local excision: Margins depend on Breslow thickness.
  3. Sentinel lymph node biopsy: Indicated for lesions >1 mm in thickness.
  4. Advanced cases:
    • Immunotherapy (e.g., immune checkpoint inhibitors).
    • Targeted therapy (BRAF/MEK inhibitors for BRAF-mutant melanoma).
    • Interferon-α: Prevents metastasis in high-risk cases.

Incorrect Options:

Option A) Condylomata lata:

  • Associated with secondary syphilis, these are smooth, moist, flat-topped, and highly contagious warty lesions, typically found in the anogenital region or mucous membranes. They lack the asymmetry, irregular borders, and color variations seen in malignant melanoma.

Option B) Mole:

  • Moles (benign melanocytic nevi) are symmetric lesions with uniform color, smooth borders, and no significant changes over time. They do not exhibit the irregular and evolving features of malignant melanoma.

Option D) Basal cell carcinoma:

  • This is the most common skin cancer, presenting as a pearly or translucent papule with telangiectasias, often on sun-exposed areas. It rarely shows pigmentation or the asymmetry and color variation seen in malignant melanoma.

questions.text: A baby presents to the OPD; the image below shows the findings. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer D - Capillary Hemangioma:

  • The images show a bright red, raised, well-demarcated lesion commonly seen in infants.

  • Capillary hemangiomas (strawberry hemangiomas) are benign vascular tumors that typically appear after birth, grow rapidly, and regress spontaneously.

  • They are superficial hemangiomas composed of proliferating endothelial cells.

  • Commonly occur on the face, scalp, trunk, or extremities.

  • Most resolve by 5–7 years of age without treatment.

Infantile Hemangioma (Capillary Hemangioma)

Feature

Capillary Hemangioma

Cause

Proliferation of immature endothelial cells

Appearance

Bright red, raised lesion with a well-demarcated border

Onset

Appears within first few weeks after birth

Growth Pattern

Rapid growth for months, then gradual involution

Resolution

90% regress by 5–7 years of age

Treatment

Observation, propranolol (if complications occur)

Portwine stain (Option A): Incorrect because port-wine stains (nevus flammeus) are flat, non-proliferative vascular malformations that do not regress.

Cavernous hemangioma (Option B): Incorrect because cavernous hemangiomas are deeper, bluish, and less well-defined.

Naevus simplex (Option C): Incorrect because naevus simplex ("salmon patch") is a flat, pink-red blanching lesion commonly seen on the forehead and nape of the neck.

Correct Answer:A) Melanoma

Explanation:

  • The given image showing a lesion with irregular borders, asymmetry, and uneven distribution of colors in the lesion is suggestive of malignant melanoma.

 

Malignant melanoma:

  • Melanoma is a malignant tumour arising from melanocytes at the epidermal-dermal junction. Though it is a rare skin cancer, it has a high mortality rate. It presents as a pigmented lesion that enlarges, ulcerates, or bleeds.

Risk factors:

  • Positive family history.
  • Fair skin.
  • Genetics: CDKN2A (chromosome 9p21), MC1R, and TYR genes.
  • Nevus:
    • Congenital melanocytic nevi.
    • Junctional nevi.
    • Atypical nevi.
    • Dysplastic nevi.
  • Fitzpatrick Type 1 skin.
  • UV light.

Investigations:

  • Clinical examination.
  • Dermoscopy.
  • Biopsy.
  • Immunohistochemistry: The markers are S-100, HMB-45 (the most specific), Melan-A (MART-1), and MITF.
  • CT scan.

Management:

  • Wide local excision (with margins measured before excision and determined by Breslow depth, sentinel lymph node biopsy indicated for tumours with a depth of >1.0 mm).
  • If the tumour is aggressive:
    • Immunotherapy.
    • Chemotherapy.
    • Targeted therapy.
  • Interferon-𝛼 is the only adjuvant treatment that has documented beneficial effects on overall survival.

Incorrect Options:

Hyperpigmentation (Option B):

  • Generalized or localized increased skin pigmentation due to conditions like melasma, Addison’s disease, or post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation.
  • Does not present with an irregular, evolving lesion.

Basal Cell Carcinoma (Option C):

  • Pearly, translucent nodule with telangiectasia.
  • Slow-growing and rarely metastasizes.
  • May have central ulceration ("rodent ulcer").

Squamous Cell Carcinoma (Option D):

  • Scaly, erythematous plaque or ulcer with crusting.
  • Often seen in chronically sun-exposed areas.
  • More locally invasive, with some potential for metastasis.

questions.text: Which type of skin cancer is commonly associated with the depicted cutaneous horn in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A : Squamous cell carcinoma

  • Cutaneous horns, also known as cornu cutaneum, are conical or cylindrical projections that appear on the skin. They are composed of keratin, the same protein found in hair and nails. Cutaneous horns can develop on various areas of the body, but they are most commonly found on sun-exposed areas, such as the face, ears, and hands.
  • While cutaneous horns themselves are not cancerous, they can be associated with underlying skin conditions, including squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). In fact, approximately 20% of cutaneous horns are found to be associated with SCC. The horn-like projection is often a result of the buildup of keratinized material over an underlying skin lesion, such as a precancerous actinic keratosis or an invasive SCC. The presence of a cutaneous horn should raise suspicion for an underlying malignancy, particularly SCC

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Melanoma - Generally being a form of skin cancer that involves the melanocytes (pigment-forming cells). These cancers are aggressive as they spread out widely.

Option C: BCC - Basal cell carcinoma is a type of skin cancer that occurs from damaged DNA due to exposure to ultraviolet rays and thus leading to the carcinomatous formation in the basal cell epithelium.

Option D: Actinic keratosis - Occurring in older people due to prolonged exposure to sun rays for years. In this condition, there occur rough and scaly types of skin. Thus due to long exposure to the sun, the skin becomes hard, rough, and scaly though a few of them lead to a cancerous state.
